line_1: What is become of a' his fun?
line_2: Alak! his joyfu' days are done;

line_1: What is become of a' his fun?
line_2: Or else he's pawn'd his dancing shoon,

line_1: On one side Folly sits, by some call'd Fun,
line_2: And, on the other, his arch-patron LUN.

line_1: May I ne'er grow too grave, not to join in the fun,
line_2: When my lord cracks a joke, or the squire cuts a pun,

line_1: He praised a poacher, precious child of fun!
line_2: Who shot the keeper with his own spring-gun;

line_1: Thou lik'st too well a bit of fun.
line_2: At work! quoth you; — but little's done,

line_1: P.S. Lucrece for half a crown will show you fun,
line_2: But Mrs. Oldfield is become a nun.

line_1: 'Twas ae night lately, in my fun,
line_2: I gaed a rovin wi' the gun,

line_1: 'Twas ae night lately, in my fun,
line_2: An' brought a Paitrick to the grun',

line_1: 'Twas ae night lately, in my fun,
line_2: And, as the twilight was begun,

line_1: No morning ray! no setting fun,
line_2: No painted sky — shall be unsung,

line_1: Thinks I to myself, they are after some Fun,
line_2: And I'll see what they're doing as sure as a Gun:

line_1: Dear Mother I think this is excellent Fun,
line_2: But, if all I must write, I should never have done:

line_1: Dear Mother I think this is excellent Fun,
line_2: So myself I subscribe your most dutiful Son,

line_1: One would think to be wet must be very good Fun;
line_2: How the Misses did huddle and scuddle, and run;

line_1: Tho' here, some add, this piece of fun,
line_2: Was but contriv'd for sake o'th' pun.
